comments:
My app starts up three threads.  As each object gets created and their threads
started, various breakpoints are set.  My first breakpoint is hit in my first
object, and while I'm stopped there, another breakpoint gets hit in another
thread.  There is an immediate crash of the debugger with a "Send report" dialog
(running on Windows XP) showing an access protection error in jvm.dll.  Only
happens when running under eclipse.

I'm starting eclipse using the -vm flag, and have tried both 1.3.1_07 and 1.4.2,
but the problem happens in both.

Other members on the team are seeing the same behavior in other applications.

Which VM are you using for the application you are debugging?
You are crashing the debugged application not Eclipse correct?

This problem happend with v3M1, but it took about 20-30 seconds for the crash to
happen. With the M3 build, the problem is worse because it crashes immediately
when the breakpoint hits in some other thread.
Can you provide a sample test case - i.e. program and breakpoint locations?

To answer the previous questions, I'm using the 1.3.1_07 VM to run the 
application.  And yes, it's the debugged application that's crashing...not 
Eclipse.

I'm trying to build up a sample, but complexity seems to be part of the 
issue.  Haven't been able to put together a simple one yet. This is part of a 
messaging application using JMS...it may only happen as part of that 
environment.

I have some error log details to share on this one.  There are three error log
entries generated:

I am seeing this identical behavior using Windows XP, Eclipse 2.1.1, JDK 1.4.2-
b28.  My case also involves hitting breakpoints in multiple threads, likely at 
the same time.  I am seeing the same stack traces (line #s are the same so I 
won't bother posting.  Other users at my company are seeing similar problems on 
2.1.1.

We really need a test case. We debug Eclipse with breakpoints in multiple 
threads all the time and we don't have this problem.

I've been trying like crazy to get a test case that shows the problem, but I 
haven't had any luck...works like a champ.  Does the stack trace data I sent 
not point you to the trouble spot?

We are really suffering with this...two different apps are showing the 
problem. I'm lucky with mine, since I can easily turn off 2 of the 3 threads, 
making it effectively a single-threaded app.  But the other folks are having 
to drop back to doing println's to debug their way through the other app.

What other options do we have?  I don't think our management is going to let 
me send production code. I might be able to arrange a PCAnywhere session. Or 
perhaps you could create a special build with some debug information spit out 
in these trouble spots identified by the stack trace?

We are also experiencing this same problem and it is causing us no end of 
trouble trying to debug applications.

Here is some more information that we have observed to hopefully track down and 
resolve this (what we view to be serious) problem.

We have observed this problem with an application we are developing that uses 
approximately 200ish threads. We have also observed this problem when turning 
off a bunch of threads leaving approximately 30 threads.

The application being debugged runs within the 1.3.1 VM. Some members of the 
team are using 1.4.1 to run Eclipse and some are using 1.3.1 to run Eclipse. 
All team members have observed the VM crashing when hitting a breakpoint. The 
VM exits immediately and the same stack trace as already submitted is observed 
in the Eclipse log.

Interestingly, sometimes (and only sometimes) we have managed to get everything 
to work as expected by disabling all of the breakpoints in the application, 
making sure it starts fine and passes one of the breakpoints you are interested 
in. Then set the breakpoint, cross fingers, and hope that it picks up the 
breakpoint without crashing. Once one breakpoint has been hit successfully 
everything normally works. However sometimes when stepping over code it just 
randomly exits. We are not sure if this is the same stack trace though.

I have a little bit more information from our shop, something similar to what
Samant noticed. The problem is much worse when you have a stack window open and
it's being updated quite a lot as your can see the thumb resizing around and
moving. If you wait until that initially settles down before setting
breakpoints, it seems to be better behaved.

We felt like things were also worse when running Eclipse on one JVM (e.g.,
1.4.2) but debugging a project on a different JVM (e.g., 1.3.1_07).

We put a developer on this to try to cook up an example app that would
demonstrate it, but as I've said from the outset, it seems that complexity is
part of the puzzle...non-trivial applications don't seem to demonstrate it.

Thanks for the update - we're hoping to see the example app that causes the 
problem.
Is there any update available here?

I haven't seen this issue for a while now.  I think it got fixed somewhere
around M6.  It was definitely a bug, and it seems to be gone now.  The only
scary thing about that is that bugs that go away by themselves can come back by
themselves.

I would say close this issue for now.  If it shows up again, a new bug will be
reported.

Other prople may continue to see it, and may have a different opinion.
